sn56.15:0.2: 2. Rolling Forth the Wheel of Dhamma
sn56.15:1.1: “Mendicants, do you remember the four noble truths that I taught?”
sn56.15:1.2: When he said this, one of the mendicants said to the Buddha:
sn56.15:1.5: “Sir, I remember that suffering is the first noble truth you’ve taught;
sn56.15:1.6: the origin of suffering is the second;
sn56.15:1.7: the cessation of suffering is the third;
sn56.15:1.8: and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering is the fourth.
sn56.15:1.9: That’s how I remember the four noble truths as you’ve taught them.”
sn56.15:2.2: It’s good that you remember the four noble truths as I’ve taught them.
sn56.15:2.3: Suffering is the first noble truth I’ve taught, and that’s how you should remember it.
sn56.15:2.4: The origin of suffering is the second;
sn56.15:2.5: the cessation of suffering is the third;
sn56.15:2.6: and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering is the fourth.
sn56.15:2.7: That’s how you should remember the four noble truths as I’ve taught them.
sn56.15:3.1: That’s why you should practice meditation …”
